title: James Scott Bowerbank
text:
James Scott Bowerbank (14 July 1797 – 8 March 1877) was a British <a href="Natural%20history">naturalist</a> and <a href="palaeontologist">palaeontologist</a>.
Biography.
Bowerbank was born in <a href="Bishopsgate">Bishopsgate</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, and succeeded in conjunction with his brother to his father's distillery, in which he was actively engaged until 1847.
In early years <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a> and natural history, especially <a href="botany">botany</a>, engaged much of his attention; he became an enthusiastic worker at the <a href="microscope">microscope</a>, studying the structure of <a href="animal%20shell">shell</a>s, <a href="coral">coral</a>s, <a href="moss%20agate">moss agate</a>s, and flints. He also formed an extensive collection of fossils. The organic remains of the <a href="London%20Clay">London Clay</a> attracted particular attention, and about the year 1836 he and six other workers founded The London Clay Club – the members comprising Dr Bowerbank, <a href="Frederick%20Erasmus%20Edwards">Frederick E. Edwards</a> (1799–1875), author of "The Eocene Mollusca" (<a href="Palaeontographical%20Society">Palaeontograph. Soc.</a>), <a href="Searles%20Valentine%20Wood">Searles Valentine Wood</a>, <a href="John%20Morris%20%28geologist%29">John Morris</a>, <a href="Alfred%20White%20%28zoologist%29">Alfred White (zoologist)</a>, <a href="Nathaniel%20Wetherell">N. T. Wetherell</a>, surgeon of Highgate (1800–1875), and <a href="James%20De%20Carle%20Sowerby">James De Carle Sowerby</a>. In 1840, Bowerbank published "A History of the Fossil Fruits and Seeds of the London Clay", and two years later he was elected <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20Royal%20Society">Fellow of the Royal Society</a>.
In 1847 he suggested the establishment of a society for the publication of undescribed British Fossils, and thus originated the <a href="Palaeontographical%20Society">Palaeontographical Society</a>. From 1844 until 1864 he did much to encourage a love of natural science by being at home every Monday evening at his residence in Park Street, <a href="Islington">Islington</a>, and afterwards in <a href="Highbury%20Grove">Highbury Grove</a>, where the treasures of his museum, his 4 microscopes, and his personal assistance were at the service of every earnest student. He became specially interested in the study of <a href="sea%20sponge">sponge</a>s, and he was author of "A Monograph of the British Spongiadae" in 4 vols., published by the <a href="Ray%20Society">Ray Society</a>, 1864–1882. He retired in 1864 to <a href="St%20Leonards-on-Sea">St Leonards-on-Sea</a>, where he died on 8 March 1877.
